description.plain:
TV on the Radio are an American indie rock band formed in 2001 in Brooklyn, New York.

The group has released several EPs including their debut Young Liars (2003), and five studio albums: Desperate Youth, Blood Thirsty Babes (2004), Return to Cookie Mountain (2006), Dear Science (2008), Nine Types of Light (2011), and Seeds (2014).

For most of the band’s existence, the core TV on the Radio lineup has been Tunde Adebimpe (vocals/loops), David Andrew Sitek (guitars/keyboards/loops), Kyp Malone (vocals/guitars/bass/loops) and Jaleel Bunton (drums/vocals/loops/guitars) as official members. Gerard Smith (bass/keyboards) was with the band from 2005 until his death in 2011.

songs.title: Wolf Like Me

description.plain:
The single that put TV on the Radio on the map en route to the huge success that was their album Return to Cookie Mountain, in 2006.

Tunde tells the story of becoming a werewolf as an allegory for the uncontrollable desire that he has for the recipient of the song.

songs.full_title: DLZ by TV on the Radio
songs.title: DLZ

description.plain:
Written by Adebimpe, this song was released in 2008 on TV on the Radio’s third studio album, Dear Science.

Although it was never released as a single, DLZ is one of the band’s most popular songs. This popularity strongly has to do with the fact that the song was featured on season 2, episode 10 of Breaking Bad.

The acronym DLZ stands for Dawn of the Loser, which is featured in the last lines of the song.

songs.full_title: Staring at the Sun by TV on the Radio
songs.title: Staring at the Sun

description.plain:
The song was first released in 2003 in TV on the Radio’s EP Young Liars. Another version, with a shortened intro, was released in 2004 in the band’s album Desperate Youth, Blood Thirsty Babes and also as a single.

David Sitek, the group’s lead guitarist/multi-instrumentalist, said in a Pitchfork interview from 2006 that this song was written in two days.

The lyrics are based on a Sufi poem from 13th century Persian writer Rumi, called “No room for form”, about transcendence, death and love.

songs.full_title: Happy Idiot by TV on the Radio
songs.title: Happy Idiot

description.plain:
The lead single from TV on the Radio’s fifth studio album Seeds, “Happy Idiot” is a song about getting over a lost love through just forgetting about them.

This track received a music video courtesy of
Will Ferrell-co-owned website Funny or Die. In the video, the band is joined by legendary funny man Paul “Pee Wee Herman” Reubens and former Doctor Who star Karen Gillan.

http://www.funnyordie.com/videos/b6fff03d4e/tv-on-the-radio-happy-idiot-feat-paul-reubens-and-karen-gillan

songs.full_title: Family Tree by TV on the Radio
songs.title: Family Tree

description.plain:
“Family Tree” swirls with warm electronic beats and harmonics that detail the story of two lovers and the prejudice they face from one of their families.

It’s a track that’s instantly relatable to any couple who has ever been subjected to discrimination either in race, gender, or sexuality. Bittersweet, relevant, and gorgeously produced, “Family Tree” remains one of TVOTR’s most poignant songs.

body.plain: I Was a Lover is about life in New York after 9/11. In the shadow of a rapidly gentrifying New York, our narrator addresses fears of selling out in a new millennium.

songs.full_title: Teardrop by Massive Attack
songs.title: Teardrop

songs.lyrics:
12 ContributorsI Was a Lover LyricsI was a lover before this war
Held up in a luxury suite, behind a well-barricaded door
Now that I've cleaned up, gone legit
I can see clearly, round hole
Round hole, square peg don't fit

I'm locked in my bedroom, so send back the clowns
My clone wears a brown shirt
And I seduce him when there's no one around
Mano y mano on a bed of nails
Bring it on like a storm
'Til I knock the wind out of his sails
And we don't make eye contact when we have run-ins in town
Just a barely polite nod
And nervous stares towards the ground
I once joined a priest class, plastic, inert
Slow-danced with commerce
Like a lens up a skirt
And we liked to party
And we kept it live
And we had a three volume tome of contemporary slang
To keep a handle on all this jive

Ennui unbridled, let's talk to kill the time
How many styles did you cycle through before you were mine?
And it's been a while since we went wild and that's all fine
But we're sleepwalking through this trial
And it's really a crime, it's really a crime, it's really a crime
It's really criminal
You might also likeWe're busy tempting like fate's on the nod
Running on empty, bourbon and God
It's been a while though since we knew the way
And it's been even longer
Since our plastic priest class had a goddamned thing
To say

I was a lover before this war
I was a lover before this war
I was a lover before this war4Embed

songs.full_title: Love Dog by TV on the Radio
songs.title: Love Dog

description.plain: In a way, “Love Dog” acts as a counterpoint to TVOTR’s 2006 single, “Wolf Like Me”. But in lieu of savage guitars and lust-packed lyrics, “Love Dog” drips with tender pathos and lovelorn emotion. The howls here are softer, gentler and the protagonist here is characterized as a canine wrought with unrequited devotion, not reciprocated desire.

songs.full_title: Second Song by TV on the Radio
songs.title: Second Song

description.plain:
The narrator is an addict.
He starts his day, knowing he’s going to have to make a decision to use or not. He’s tried to kick it in many different ways. He still needs to make the decision, each day. His body is in withdrawals; his hands are shaking.
And when night comes he knows it’s the only way to survive. He takes the drug.
The rest of the song is the trip. He is connected to the light of the world. Though his body is connected to the heartless “real world,” he knows his love for the drug is forever.

description.plain: This is the last track on TV on the Radio’s major release EP “Young Liars”.  This is an a cappella version of the Pixies song “Mr. Grieves”, which was off of their 1989 album “Doolittle”. The obscure lyrics seem to approach the subject of death brought about by the human destruction of the environment.

songs.full_title: Killer Crane by TV on the Radio
songs.title: Killer Crane

description.plain: As the Wikipedia page on Gerard Smith puts it: “The song "Killer Crane” from Nine Types Of Light was written about the band coming to terms with Smith’s impending death, and the song’s video serves as a tribute to him, featuring many shots of Smith.“ In its essence, "Killer Crane” is a testament to a friendship that surpasses the limits of a lifetime. A profound declaration of acceptance towards the inevitable end of things, both good and difficult.

songs.lyrics:
10 ContributorsLet the Devil In LyricsBeg the bee's forgiveness as it's falling from your sleeve
Watch its guts pump poison into sting
Watch it reach completeness, see it fall asleep
Legs above fold in eternal dream

Oh, that calls to mind a joke, an off coloring
About these fools blindfolded, drugged, and raped and left laughing
They let the devil in, he brought his pirate friends
They brought a hunger for blood and flesh and bone and skin

So teeth left chattering and tongues flexed to sing
Got dressed up in so many fancy things

Is it a waste of time? Tell me if you mind
Me dipping into useless sentimentality
A rant on how things used to be when this shit was free
I answered my own question, I can hear the crickets yawning
But in the back pocket of a discarded pair of jeans
Is still a priceless ticket to the grandest opening
So when the chariot arrives you'd best enjoy the ride
'Cause when we get to Heaven's gate we're not getting inside

Better beg forgiveness
Better drop to knees
Better find your ticket
Before we join the bees

songs.full_title: Poppy by TV on the Radio
songs.title: Poppy

description.plain: “Poppy” paints a picture of an open relationship where the narrator is content with the relationship on the basis of mutual individualism.  Neither party is thinking about a family “mommy” or “poppy” and the narrator is grateful that each of them are separate.  It could be a casual “friends-with-benefits” type of relationship or an open relationship in which each is relatively independent of each other.  What makes “Poppy” such an interesting love song is that it is principally concerned with non-attachment, and not feeling glued to your significant other.

songs.lyrics:
3 ContributorsNetti Fretti Lyrics[Italian Singing]

[Radio DJ]
You are tuned in to WQED Classical 89.9 on your FM dial. The time is now 3:15. We just heard 'Netti Fretti Con Volante', written in 1899 by the renowned Scotch-Italian composer Shamus Vitilago, preformed by the choir St. Martin-in-the-Field in Minnesota. DJ Bullshit conducting, this was recorded just last year, in Minnesota. Not much is known about Shamus Vitilago; he was well renowned, but mostly for his antics, for his theater. He was a midget, peg-legged drunkard who toured incessantly with the circus, and also had an unparalleled ear for dissonance and atonality. He lead a strange life and suffered an equally strange fate. He was beaten to death by the painter Caravaggio in 1899 after debuting the song we just heard now. The litelul- litera- excuse me... literal translation for which follows as such:

[?]; This whore has rescued me, necrophilia can wait
[?]; My madness explains its need to kill
[?]; Us on her bed, her godless bed, begin our gruesome exchange
[?]; A burning net with wings is what love is

And the chorus of the song, that magnificent sweeping chorus:

[?]; I pull out on the brink of unconsciousness and spackle Gena with my ejaculate

Bold images. Strong, strong images, wonderfully sung. The song was dedicated to Caravaggio and his beautiful new wife, Gena. Classical 89.9, the time is now 3:20. Ping-Pong recording examples will be next, input select switches are on. Please stay tunedYou might also likeEmbed
